title: Can filing for bankruptcy keep a condominium home owners association-"hoa" from foreclosing on our home for past due "hoa" dues
question: condominium home owners associations-"hoa"-in los angeles,county,california u.s.a.-why can they discriminate and give favors to various home owners in a condominium home complex ?
answers: The filing of a bankruptcy creates an automatic stay which stops all legal action against you and your property. The short answer to your question is yes. The longer question is what do you intend to do with the property after you filed the bankruptcy? If you filed a Chapter 7 either the property will be sold by the bankruptcy trustee and the HOA arrears will be paid from the proceeds of the sale or the trustee will abandon the asset and, once the bankruptcy is over, the HOA will continue with its foreclosure after the bankruptcy is closed. If you filed a Chapter 13 then you must cure the HOA arrears through your plan of reorganization and stay current on your post-peitition HOA dues in order to keep the property or surrender the property through your plan. As to your favoratisim quesiton I do not know the answer to that one.

I have several clients who have filed chapter 13 bankruptcy for the sole purpose of catching up on HOA arrears. I also have clients who intended to surrender the property and filed chapter 7 for the purpose of discharging unpaid dues that had accrued up until the date of filing; even in chapter 7, the property owner remains on the hook for unpaid post-petition dues.

You certainly can delay the foreclosure by filing a bankruptcy petition. However, if the HOA is foreclosing they already have a lien and the lien will remain. Additionally, post petition fees are not discharged.

So, if you want to keep your condo you will eventually have to pay all fees, i.e., the ones that became due before your BK filing because there is a lien on the property and the ones that became due after filing because you are personally responsible for them.

You should personally consult bankruptcy counsel to determine if a Chapter 13 bankruptcy would allow you to pay your past-due HOA fees over time to avoid foreclosure.

I practice in Washington State and the laws are different state-to-state, but the bankruptcy code is a federal law and only discharges personal liability. So filing bankruptcy could (a) delay an association foreclosure for a period of time and/or (b) discharge you from personal liability for the debt. However, it is likely that even if your bankruptcy were successful, the association would retain its ability to foreclose upon the lien against your property (liens are not affected or discharged by bankruptcy).

You should consult with an attorney who is familiar with bankruptcy law AND HOA law if you can find one; we represent associations in Washington and find all too often that bankruptcy debtors are unfortunately given incorrect information by their bankruptcy attorneys.

In general... when a homeowner fails to pay HOA dues, the HOA can bring suit for the money and place a lien on the home for dues. In general, bankruptcy removes or attacks personal debts and does not remove liens. Of course, as with all general statements there are exceptions.

- Paul
